title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SEATTLE (AP) – History arrived not with a whisper, but with the thunderous roar of the KeyArena crowd. On this night, the final score, a 112-96 victory for the Seattle SuperSonics over the Vancouver Grizzlies, was merely a subplot to a singular, breathtaking performance. This was the night Detlef Schrempf authored a masterpiece.

The German forward was simply unstoppable, pouring in a career-high and franchise-record 40 points in a surgical display of offensive brilliance. Schrempf did it from everywhere, connecting on an astonishing 16 of 22 from the field and a perfect 8-for-8 from the free-throw line. He wasn't just scoring; he was dominating, adding 10 rebounds for a powerful double-double.

While Gary Payton orchestrated the Sonics' attack with 15 points and 14 assists, and Vin Baker provided a sturdy 18 points, they were a powerful supporting cast to the Schrempf show. The Grizzlies, led by 19 points from Blue Edwards and a strong 17-point, 12-rebound effort from Bryant Reeves, simply had no answer for the onslaught.

Every time Vancouver threatened to close the gap, Schrempf answered. A mid-range jumper, a hard drive to the basket, a clutch rebound—his 40 points were a relentless tide washing away any hope of a Grizzlies upset.

In the end, the statistics were staggering, but the memory was more profound. One player, on one electrifying night, etched his name into the Seattle record books. The Sonics earned the win, but Detlef Schrempf owned the night, delivering a performance for the ages that transcended the final score.
